subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary, script not working
msgSnippet: It s my personal belief that the dictionary I created was only a guide and learning tool. I also believe that QS should be used in a way that reflects each
messageBody:
It's my personal belief that the dictionary I created was only a guide and learning tool. I also believe that QS should be used in a way that reflects each individual's unique accent. The over all word form, should only be a guide to our reading.

John Cowan wrote:

pgabhart scripsit:
> The dictionary, however it was produced does not use #34, the short "o"
> sound, which Read illustrated with the word "O-x." It should appear in
> words such as "hot," "pot", "hobby," "stocky," etc. The long "A-h"
> sound (#32), instead, is used throughout this dictionary. Examples:
> "father," "calm." "alarm." This is a longer vowel and should not be
> mistaken for #34.

That's because your base dictionary was of American English, where
the vowels Ox and Ah have merged (except in Eastern New England).
To make things worse, Ox, Ah, and Awe have merged in the Western U.S.,
and increasingly so elsewhere in the country.

IIUC, Quikscript represents a conservative variety of RP, one in which
"poor" and "pour" have not yet merged.

See http://www.phon. ucl.ac.uk/ home/wells/ accents_spelling reform.htm for
an excellent explanation of all these difficulties.

--
John Cowan http://ccil. org/~cowan cowan@...
'My young friend, if you do not now, immediately and instantly, pull
as hard as ever you can, it is my opinion that your acquaintance in the
large-pattern leather ulster' (and by this he meant the Crocodile) 'will
jerk you into yonder limpid stream before you can say Jack Robinson.'
--the Bi-Coloured- Python-Rock- Snake
